The sergeant, Peter Viola, was found not guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn in a case that drew wide notice because the woman he was accused of assaulting, Ann B. Dodds, is considered a driving force behind community-improvement efforts in her Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trial Is Moved for 2 Charged in Burning Of a Brooklyn Man
nytimes_articles.abstract: The trial of two white Florida men accused of burning a tourist from Brooklyn because he was black has been moved to West Palm Beach.   After eight futile days of jury selection here, Judge Donald Evans of State Circuit Court ordered the trial moved beyond the Tampa television market. A tentative starting date of Aug. 23 has been set.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jettison the Space Station
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is finally time for Congress to acknowledge that the proposed space station is too expensive to continue while the Federal Government is scrambling to cut expenditures.    There's no doubt that the Clinton Administration has made a valiant, good-faith attempt to pare down the costs of the program. The White House ordered the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to come up with three proposals for redesigning the station to cut costs drastically. And it set up a review committee of experts to judge the worthiness of the proposals and the accuracy of the cost estimates.

nytimes_articles.headline: Officers Jeer Perjury Conviction
nytimes_articles.abstract: More than 100 police officers staged a boisterous impromptu demonstration outside a Manhattan courtroom yesterday afternoon after a police officer in the 34th Precinct in upper Manhattan was convicted of perjury.   The police officer, John Rossi, 28, faces up to seven years in prison on perjury charges stemming from a gun possession case. He was tried without a jury and found guilty by Jeffrey M. Atlas, an acting State Supreme Court judge.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Budget Too Much Like Perot's
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ross Perot told voters he would reduce the deficit. So did Bill Clinton. But Mr. Clinton added a more profound promise: to tilt Federal spending toward investments in education, training, technology and research. In his February budget message President Clinton lived up to his promises, proposing to cut the deficit by $500 billion over five years, yet add $200 billion in programs to raise public and private investment.   Now Congress is about to dispose of Mr. Clinton's investment plans. Unless the Administration lobbies effectively, Congress will pass a budget that focuses on deficit reduction and virtually ignores economic growth.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: NEW YORK CITY  A DISTURBANCE'S LONG SHADOW   Propelled by the imminent release of a state report on racial disturbances in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the long-simmering controversy over how the Dinkins administration handled the 1991 violence has moved to the forefront of the mayoral campaign. A1. RENT CONTROLS STILL ON HOLD   For the second time in a week, New York State Senate and Assembly leaders have agreed to extend the state's rent regulations for a brief period while they continue discussing whether to weaken regulations on certain luxury apartments. Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, announced they have agreed to extend the existing rent-regulation law for seven days. B3.   Against the backdrop of a legislative tug of war over rent regulation, the city's Rent Guidelines Board votes on proposed increases for rent-stabilized apartments. B3.

nytimes_articles.headline: Washington Talk; Stronger Congress Tied To Fewer Committees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Congressional reform means so many different things to different people that it is no wonder not much seems to be changing.   When freshmen representatives discuss it, they usually mean radical changes like term limits and huge cuts in staff.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democrats Disunited : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I resent various implications that there is an "Elvis" in the White House. Elvis would have been much better.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helping Kids Grab On to the Future
nytimes_articles.abstract: The dark blue '68 Firebird convertible seems out of place cruising the local streets between Campbell Park and the adjacent Martin Luther King Jr. projects.   It's a California car, and not just because of the license plates. With the white ragtop down, it looks as if it should have a surfboard jutting up from the back seat, cruising down the Pacific Coast Highway toward Malibu or Point Dume.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's been a long haul for three post-graduate fellows in cardiothoracic surgery at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, both in Manhattan. So their mentors decided to say a formal farewell, with funny and poignant touches.    Dr. O. WAYNE ISOM, chairman of cardiothoracic surgery at New York Hospital, and Dr. ROBERT J. GINSBERG, his counterpart at Sloan-Kettering, are giving a dinner tomorrow at Le Cirque for this year's group: Dr. JOHN BROWN, Dr. JAMES COUNCE and Dr. DAVID M. JABONS, who were chosen from more than 60 applicants and who have performed some 1,500 operations in two years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democrats Disunited : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary McGrory's lament ("One-Party Government, So to Speak," June 16) that "one-party" government is not what it is cracked up to be, misses the point. Far from being an affair of egos and media hamming, the divisions in the Democratic

nytimes_articles.headline: Whether Positive or Negative, Result of Prostate Cancer Test Can Create Maze of Questions
nytimes_articles.abstract: TWO years ago, Richard Howe, 64 years old, a retired oil company executive in Houston, asked his doctor for a new prostate cancer test that he had seen advertised. When Mr. Howe's results came back, they were positive, catapulting him into a world of medical decision-making in the face of enormous uncertainty.    But, Mr. Howe says, he is sure he did the right thing. His doctor found cancerous cells in his prostate, Mr. Howe had an operation to remove the tumor, and now, he says, he is probably cured of a cancer that might have killed him.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bid Is $148.1 Million. Going, Going . . .
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bidding for the Baltimore Orioles jumped to $148.1 million yesterday after two potential ownership groups increased their offers for the team.    The latest offer was made on behalf of a group of Baltimore investors that includes a lawyer, PETER ANGELOS; sports broadcaster JIM McKAY, tennis player PAM SHRIVER and LEONARD WINEGLASS, chairman of Maryland based retailer Merry-Go-Round Enterprises.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; New Evil. New Empire. Same Fun.
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Night Manager  By John le Carre  429 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.    In John le Carre's last suspense novel, "The Secret Pilgrim," he put a final punctuation mark on the cold war by having George Smiley, his legendary, all-too-human character, sum up his career for the next generation of British spies. Something one of Smiley's colleagues said at the end of that rich and rather philosophical novel remains in mind: "Now we had defeated Communism, we were going to have to set about defeating capitalism."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; Musically Sparring, in a Friendly Way, of Course
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jazz has always used a friendly competition to turn the burners up under soloists, and George Wein, the founder of the JVC Festival and the pianist at Monday night's show, "After 45 Years: George Wein and the Newport All-Stars," at Town Hall, took advantage of the tradition. The concert, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, was defined by two encounters during the second half. The trumpeters Doc Cheatham and Jon Faddis came out and performed a series of startlingly witty and empathetic duets. Then Gerry Mulligan and Wynton Marsalis appeared and proceeded to push each other to increasingly vibrant and intricate improvisations.   The 39-year-old Mr. Faddis and the 88-year-old Mr. Cheatham are regular sparring partners, and after Mr. Cheatham shaped a perfect solo on "I've Got the World on a String," Mr. Faddis joined him for a duet on "On the Sunny Side of the Street." Mr. Faddis soloed first, sending clear high notes to the ceiling. Then Mr. Cheatham improvised, fooling with the melody, only to start singing the song. "I do not know the words," he sang, scatting a bit until he came to the line "I'd be rich as Rockefeller," which he interpreted as "I'd be rich as George Wein."

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: SOCCER  U.S. Squanders Lead, and Heads Home  The United States wasted a three-goal lead in the last 25 minutes and was eliminated from the America Cup with a 3-3 tie against Venezuela last night in Quito, Ecuador. The Americans went ahead on goals by Chris Henderson in the 20th minute, Peter Vermes in the 36th minute and Dominic Kinnear in the 51st. But Jose Dolgetta scored in the 65th and 77th minutes and Miguel Echanaussi in the final minute. The United States, 2-8-10 this year, was playing for the first time in the America Cup, South America's biennial championship. The Americans, who are missing most of their good players, previously lost to Uruguay, 1-0, and Ecuador, 2-0, and had been the only team not to score in the tournament. The tie clinched advancement to the quarterfinals for Uruguay (1-0-1), which played Ecuador late last night. Venezuela (0-1-2) is unlikely to advance as one of the two-best third-place teams because of a minus-5 goal differential. (AP) YACHT RACING  Block Island Race Finally Begins  The 169 sailboats gathered off Rhode Island for Block Island Race Week finally got started yesterday after light winds and fog on Monday postponed the start for a day. The fleet, separated into 14 divisions, managed two races yesterday in 12-23-knot breezes. Dennis Conner, sailing his 60-foot yacht, Winston, crossed the finish line first in both races as an unofficial entry. Conner, four-time defender of the America's Cup, said last week that he was using Race Week as a shakedown series for Winston. The new ocean racerwill be sailing trans-Atlantic July 3 on its way to the start of the Whitbread Round the World Race, scheduled for late September. First place under the big boats' handicap rule was Infinity, a new 50-foot sloop designed by Nelson/Marek and owned by John Thomson of Port Washington, L.I. On board Infinity was Tom Whidden, Conner's tactician in several America's Cup campaigns.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Are Soldiers For - To Stand By and Salute?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last week, UN "peacekeepers" in Somalia and in Bosnia shot back. .Previously, blue-helmeted UN soldiers in these war-devastated areas had generally kept their guns holstered. Indeed, they have been alarmingly, frustratingly impotent. Called p

nytimes_articles.headline: SENATORS BRACING FOR FIGHT ON PLAN TO INCREASE TAXES
nytimes_articles.abstract: With some of their careers and perhaps the eventual success of Bill Clinton's Presidency on the line, senators prepared today to begin voting on raising taxes and curbing popular programs.   Senators from both parties agree that the budget package will pass by the end of the week on a party-line vote with almost all the Democrats in favor and all the Republicans opposed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Meal Deduction on Table, But Congress Won't Bite
nytimes_articles.abstract: One line in the Senate's budget bill, overlooked because it has never been publicly debated, would affect the tens of millions of Americans who have expense accounts. But they need not worry. It will never become law.   It would require businesses to have receipts for any expense of more than $20 for which they claim a tax deduction. The threshold is now $25.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; What Will Mets Rebuild With?
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT last, the Mets' co-owners have used the dreaded word that is baseball's synonym for surrender. The word is rebuild.   "We're here," Fred Wilpon was saying yesterday as Nelson Doubleday stood next to him, "to rebuild a championship team."

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: The American League baseball standings yesterday carried an erroneous entry in some copies for third place in the Eastern Division. That spot belonged to the Yankees; the Mets were correctly listed in last place in the Eastern Division of the National League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A table in Business Day on May 21 listing the American Stock Exchange's uncovered short sales for the month ended May 14 included some erroneous figures, which the exchange attributed to a data-processing error. Revised figures appear today on page D20, along with the June figures.

nytimes_articles.headline: What Do Teachers Want Most? Help From Parents
nytimes_articles.abstract: What's the biggest problem in American education today? Not students, but their parents, according to a nationwide survey of teachers.   By a substantial majority, teachers in the annual Metropolitan Life Survey of the American Teacher, conducted by Louis Harris & Associates, placed greater parental involvement in their children's education at the top of their list of policy priorities. Fifty-four percent of the 1,000 teachers surveyed by telephone around the country listed parental involvement as the top public-policy priority.

nytimes_articles.headline: Democrats Disunited : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Perhaps we should consider converting the White House into a fast-food emporium. It could be called The Waffle & Fudge, since that seems to be what it is chiefly putting out.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about the United States Supreme Court's decision to let stand a New York State income tax on nonresidents referred incorrectly to the status of a New Jersey Senate bill to impose a similar commuter tax on nonresidents. Late on Monday, the Senate postponed its vote until next week. The article also misstated the scope of the proposed tax in New Jersey. It would apply only to New York residents.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: Royal Trousseau : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - Her Serene Highness Princess May's trousseau is making some progress towards completion, although, as so many of the designs are being exclusively woven for the Royal bride-elect, it is difficult for the makers of the dresses, &c., to get on

nytimes_articles.headline: Arm Bosnians? Clinton Didn't Mean It
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a further sign of confusion in the Clinton Administration policy toward Bosnia, the United States today played down the significance of a letter from President Clinton to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany urging him to support a stillborn American effort to arm the Muslim Government of Bosnia.   The letter included a sentence that the German leader assumed was a marching order from the United States to lobby the European Community to allow Bosnia's Muslims to arm themselves against the Bosnian Serbs and Croats.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Compromise on Military's Gay Ban Is Discussed
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton said today that the Administration was nearing a decision on homosexuals in the military, and civilian Pentagon aides said discussions were focusing on a new option that would leave some restrictions but fewer than those proposed by a panel of generals and admirals.   The officials described the evolving proposal as an attempt to split the difference between simply lifting the ban on homosexuals and allowing them to serve but forcing them to conceal their sexuality.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "We're going to do everything to improve the aroma around here." -- NELSON DOUBLEDAY co-owner of the New York Mets.  [ B9:5. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Bosnians Divide Over New Talks To Split Country
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Alija Izetbegovic was replaced today as head of the Bosnian Government's delegation here for talks with Serbian and Croatian leaders on their plan to divide Bosnia into three ethnic states. If the plan is accepted, it will probably mean the end of an independent Bosnia and Herzegovina.    After a stormy session of the nine-member collective presidency of Bosnia, which met in Zagreb, the Croatian capital, seven members decided to attend the talks and arrived here tonight. The two others, President Izetbegovic and Vice President Ejup Ganic, returned to their capital, Sarajevo.

nytimes_articles.headline: In an Edgy Mogadishu, Relief Efforts Are in Jeopardy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Food distribution has begun again in Mogadishu after a 10-day interruption during the United Nations military operation against a Somali clan leader.   But relief officials said that although no one had starved before food distribution resumed late last week, continuing instability made relief operations increasingly difficult.

nytimes_articles.headline: Political Director Is Replaced in White House Staff Shake-Up
nytimes_articles.abstract: Continuing a staff shakeup, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, has decided to replace Rahm Emanuel, President Clinton's political director, with Joan N. Baggett, a former union lobbyist who has been Mr. Emanuel's deputy.   Mr. Emanuel will become deputy communications director, White House officials said. His replacement, which had been rumored for weeks, comes as Mr. McLarty prepares to put the final touches on his plan for reorganizing the White House operation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Treasurer Begins Review Of Legislature's Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: The State Treasurer, Samuel F. Crane, today began a review of the $15.4 billion state budget, which the Legislature passed on Monday, and will advise Gov. Jim Florio which items he should consider vetoing, said the Governor's spokesman, Jon Shure.   After little more than pro forma opposition from minority Democrats, the Legislature passed a Republican-drafted election-year budget for 1994 and sent it to Mr. Florio.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Tasks for Albany -- Pass the Gay Rights Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York State Senate's majority leader, Ralph Marino, has been stalling for months. But as the Legislature chugs toward summer recess, New Yorkers will soon know where Mr. Marino and his 34 G.O.P. colleagues stand on anti-gay bigotry.   Pending before the State Senate is an overdue civil rights bill passed in February by the Democrat-led Assembly. Like similar laws in eight states, the measure would bar discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation in employment, housing, public accommodations, education and credit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Guidelines Board Adopts New Rent Increases
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a raucous four-hour session, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night adopted rent increases for rent-stabilized apartments in New York City.   The board's action comes against the backdrop of a Legislative tug-of-war in Albany over the fate of rent regulation. Yesterday, Senate and Assembly leaders agreed to extend the state's rent regulations for seven days while they continue discussions on whether to loosen regulations on certain luxury apartments.

nytimes_articles.headline: Personal Health
nytimes_articles.abstract: THUMBS are out of style. Modern babies suck on pacifiers, now also a fashion accessory for teen-agers, who wear them in psychedelic colors around their necks and sometimes actually put them in their mouths.    Sucking is an instinct essential to the survival of all mammals, which as newborns get all their sustenance by nursing. Human babies have been observed on sonograms to suck their thumbs even before they are born.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can America Save Itself?: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The burning question we Americans must ask ourselves today is not whether we should or will save Bosnia, or restore human rights in China, or turn Russia into a capitalistic success story, but whether or not we will be able to save ourselves. Will we, as

nytimes_articles.headline: Italians in the Meadowlands? Not So Fast
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ostensibly, they were in New York to unveil Fantastic Italia, an exhibition chronicling Italian soccer that will be showcased at every city that the will be host to World Cup games next summer. But ANTONIO MATARRESE and ARRIGIO SACCHI may have had an ulterior motive in scouring the area the last few days. Matarrese, the president of the Italian Soccer Federation, and Sacchi, the national team coach, have been scouting New Jersey and New York for possible training sites for next year's opening round of the World Cup at Giants Stadium, where they will likely be placed if they qualify for the tournament.   "We have a range of options which we've found to be satisfactory," said Matarrese through a translator at a news conference at the United Nations Plaza Hotel yesterday. "We think we have found suitable sites. But it would be premature to announce them. You see, our coach is a little superstitious, so we won't name a site until we qualify."

nytimes_articles.headline: Sampras and Graf Roll Over Foes and Doubts
nytimes_articles.abstract: Less than a week ago, Pete Sampras raised his cherished serving arm in the rather mundane act of brushing his teeth and discovered his shoulder was too sore to help him carry brush to mouth. How could it launch a serve worthy of a Wimbledon campaign?   Three days of frenetic treatment and diagnoses ensued, and on the eve of his match against the Australian Neil Borwick, Sampras was still concerned that he might suffer tendon damage by pursuing the one Grand Slam title for which he's been groomed for the last decade. Sampras would love to further validate his ranking as the world's No. 1 player by winning what the tournament traditionalists consider the epitome of the genre.

nytimes_articles.headline: Olympiad in Beijing?First Weigh the Risks : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: China's pollution problem is very serious. Chinese leaders may draw comparisons with Los Angeles, but it's worse than Los Angeles. Much worse. During my two weeks in Shanghai as a commentator for a Hong Kong television station during the Asian Games, I m

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Votes to Send a Force To Uganda-Rwanda Border
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Security Council voted unanimously today to send a small peacekeeping force to monitor the Ugandan border to insure that neighboring Rwandan rebels do not smuggle weapons.   Fighting between the Rwandan Government, which is dominated by Hutu people, and an invading force led by the minority Tutsi has taken hundreds of lives. It is estimated that a million people have been displaced in the civil war, which erupted in October 1990.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Graduation Ceremony Earns Special Cheers
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT was graduation day for the Steppingstone Day School in Kew Gardens, Queens, and the 5-year-olds in their little white gowns and mortarboards started down the aisle to the strains of "Pomp and Circumstance."    For an outsider, the sight of 63 nursery-schoolers in academic procession might have appeared excessive, an exercise in cloying cuteness. But, in fact, there were no outsiders present, and all the insiders -- the parents, grandparents, friends, relatives and teachers -- understood that what was taking place in the recreation hall of St. Nicholas of Tolentine Roman Catholic Church was no frivolous mock commencement, no empty parody of a collegiate rite. No, what was going on was a fitting celebration of achievements by children born with disabilities and who next fall would be heading for public school, probably to special education classes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Tasks for Albany -- Ban Assault Weapons
nytimes_articles.abstract: The gang that pulled off four subway robberies last weekend terrorized riders with what witnesses described as automatic weapons. Mercifully, no shots were fired. But what about next time? Assault rifles like Uzis and AK-47's are the weapons of choice these days among gangs and drug dealers. Yet New York has not joined Connecticut and New Jersey in banning them. Republicans in the State Senate stand in the way.   When will they get the message that citizens who've had it with guns matter more than lobbyists? The State Assembly has approved a near-total ban on assault weapons -- the first time either house has done so. The measure might stand a chance in the Republican-controlled Senate if the majority leader, Ralph Marino of Long Island, would endorse and push it. Instead, he's neither for nor against. "He's open on it," says his spokesman, John McCardle. "He's willing to reconsider."

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943:New Guinea Battle : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA - [From our New York edition:] The largest Japanese force to be hurled against Allied lines on the ground front of New Guinea at Mubo was thrown back by Australian troops with American air support on June 21, leaving more

nytimes_articles.headline: Harazin Victim of a Brave New World
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a man whose baseball upbringing was on the business side, Al Harazin knows the significance of the bottom line. Simply but economically painfully put, if the Mets had been the contender and perhaps division champion Harazin and many others thought they would be last season and this, as many as 3 million fans who haven't gone and won't go to Shea Stadium would have bought tickets.   That converts to $36 million lost, which could have paid for nearly all of the Mets' $39 million payroll this season. That is why Harazin is the latest victim in the increasingly volatile world of general managers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dead Air: Mets Fans Tune Out In Droves
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Mets' dismal performance, which led yesterday to General Manager Al Harazin's resignation, hasn't been lost on television viewers and advertisers. Ratings and sales are down, and the Mets' long run as the darling of local television seems to be ending as the resurgent Yankees are poised to wrest the title away.   "This has not been one of our easiest years," said Tom Ryan, general sales manager of WWOR-TV/Channel 9, who listed 1982 and 1983 as tougher ones. "There are peaks and valleys in every season, and we hope our advertisers understand that. All our advertisers are still with us, which we're happy about."

nytimes_articles.headline: Beyond 'Jurassic Park': Few Jobs in Old Bones
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Kass forges through intensive courses in geology, mathematics and chemistry. He spends summer vacations searching for ancient bones in hot, dusty quarries. Words like "Mesozoic" and "velociraptor" roll easily off his tongue.   But Mr. Kass, a graduate student in paleontology at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, worries that he will not find a job once he leaves school. After all, few paleontologists have the luxury of hunting dinosaur fossils for a living, like the adventure-seeking duo in the movie "Jurassic Park." Other opportunities, including museum work, teaching and research, are almost as scarce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; Going Nowhere
nytimes_articles.abstract: Like-minded women sighed and said, "It's going to be a long summer." In Minneapolis and St. Paul, where people joke that there are only two seasons, winter and road work, you don't hear that line very much.But Operation Rescue had come to town, and those who believe abortion should stay legal were expecting the summer to be long and hot, as Wichita's had been just two summers ago.    So far, in fact, the right-wing anti-abortion group, which specializes in clinic blockades and provider harassment, has been remarkably quiet.  There were only two small demonstrations by local anti-abortion groups last weekend, one a photo op of people praying at the 10-foot-high chain-link fence that has recently gone up around the Planned Parenthood parking lot.

nytimes_articles.headline: Iran's Police Begin A Dress-Code Drive As Complaints Rise
nytimes_articles.abstract: Iran's morals police have begun a nationwide crackdown on "vice and social corruption" in city streets, but after hundreds of arrests and with public indignation running high, President Hashemi Rafsanjani has declared that the operation has gone wrong, a newspaper reported today.    More than 800 women were arrested for dress code violations in Teheran, with many detained for wearing sunglasses, witnesses said. Several clashes between the vice squads and the public were reported, and a Western European diplomat was said to have been beaten on Sunday for refusing to allow the authorities to search his car.

nytimes_articles.headline: Olympiad in Beijing?First Weigh the Risks : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "If China Wants the Olympics So Badly, Let It Have Them" (June 7):Flora Lewis describes reports that an anti-crime campaign to ensure "stability" during the 1990 Asian Games led to 12,000 executions of criminals in the per

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: The playoff matches that begin here Wednesday morning will determine two open teams and two women's teams to represent the United States in world championship play in Santiago, Chile, in September.   At least one of the successful open teams will consist largely or wholly of players making their debuts at world level. The only player involved who was a member of the 1992 American team is Eric Rodwell of Naperville, Ill., who has won three world titles. He has been added to the Reisinger team as a partner for Marty Bergen of Farmingdale, L.I., and it will be interesting to see how well they perform together.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Activated John Orton, catcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Waived Larry Gonzales, catcher. Recalled Victor Salverio, pitcher, from a rehabilitation assignment and assigned him to Palm Springs of the California League.

nytimes_articles.headline: Radio Free Europe Will Drop 7 Languages
nytimes_articles.abstract: Acting swiftly to carry out President Clinton's plan to merge all of the Government's international broadcasting operations, Radio Free Europe is set to announce termination early next week of most of its foreign language transmissions.   Since the early 1950's, Radio Free Europe and its sister station, Radio Liberty, have been broadcasting from Munich to what was the Soviet Union and five of its allies.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan Scorns Fund for Russia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Japan's Foreign Minister, Kabun Muto, said today that a Clinton Administration proposal to create a $4 billion fund to help turn Russia's state-owned enterprises into private companies was "preposterous," and added that an agreement had been reached to scale the fund back to about $500 million.   The proposal was made in April during a meeting here of the finance and foreign ministers of the Group of Seven industrial democracies. The meeting produced an agreement to provide $28 billion in aid to support Russia's transition to a capitalist economy, but the $4 billion fund was not part of that total.

nytimes_articles.headline: Young Enters Record Book With Head Down
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anthony Young, 22 straight defeats on his mind and a sad immortality on the line, wanted nothing more than for the losing to stop. The Mets played as if they had no idea of how to win. Nothing novel. Nothing changed.   And so the Mets, who are always more at odds with themselves than with their opponents, lost to the Expos, 6-3, last night at Shea Stadium. They put four errors on the scoreboard and Young's name in the record book. His 23d straight defeat equaled the sorry standard set by Cliff Curtis of the Boston Braves in 1910-11.

nytimes_articles.headline: Running in Jerusalem
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I saw your excellent June 13 article "Kollek's Last Run May Be Toughest" on the plane flying to Los Angeles. For me to run again is very difficult. Only the conviction that a Likud Party victory would bring irreparable harm to Jerusalem, Israel's capital and all its inhabitants, and possibly to the peace process, made me decide on this course. I hope the Jerusalemites will support me and I'll win, but should I lose, it will be easier to live with a mistake than with regrets.  TEDDY KOLLEK  Mayor of Jerusalem Los Angeles, June 15, 1993

nytimes_articles.headline: Nude-Dancing Bar Thrives, Despite Loss of a Liquor License
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Alfred Ciraldo decided to open a topless bar across the street from a Roman Catholic church here, he knew he would face resistance.   In the last month, he has withstood inspections by an army of city officials, a charge of "Catholic bashing" from the church's pastor and the loss of his provisional liquor license.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bradley Adds 2 Cents to Debate on Beijing
nytimes_articles.abstract: United States Senator BILL BRADLEY, Democrat of New Jersey, a former Olympic gold medalist in basketball, has joined the growing campaign against Beijing's bid to host the 2000 Games.   Bradley wrote a letter to the International Olympic Committee president, JUAN ANTONIO SAMARANCH, expressing "my strong opposition to awarding the Games to Beijing while its Government denies fundamental human rights to its citizens."

nytimes_articles.headline: Showering Could Check Lyme Disease
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Flaws Are Seen in Diagnosis and Control of Lyme Disease" (front page, June 15): I would like to contribute some observations regarding the control of Lyme disease derived from my dual role as an active officer of a hiking and climbing organization and a clinician.

nytimes_articles.headline: Defending Champs 101: Blue Jays Teach Yanks a Lesson
nytimes_articles.abstract: So this is what being a championship team is all about. Some hotshot team drifts on to your turf, walking the delicate line between pretender and contender, and it must be taught a lesson. Although it is only June, the defending champion Blue Jays slapped the Yankees with a memorable lesson on pursuing a pennant tonight.   There were so many aspects to Toronto's lesson. The Blue Jays displayed how pivotal it is to win at home, how crucial it is to remain steady when the deficit is sizable in the early innings, how important it is to rally and how integral it is to win, just win, when you have the lead in the late innings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Book Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Taking Big Chances   To many publishers, the delay of Oprah Winfrey's autobiography, which was summarily yanked by the talk-show host just three months before its scheduled publication date, was a chilling reminder of the perils of publishing books by celebrities.   Such books can be incredibly lucrative, particularly for a publishing house that hopes to subsidize a strong but unglamorous list with a blockbuster or two. Alfred A. Knopf had planned to print 750,000 copies of Ms. Winfrey's book in hard cover, and people in the industry estimated that the book could have brought in a staggering $15 million to $20 million. But the pitfalls of planning such a book are numerous, not least because many celebrities seem to work in their own orbits, with their own agendas.

nytimes_articles.headline: Human Rights Would Lose in a Beijing Olympiad
nytimes_articles.abstract: Among the six cities bidding to be host to the 2000 Olympic Games, Sydney and Beijing are the acknowledged front-runners. Their lobbying efforts will intensify this week in Lausanne, Switzerland, where the International Olympic Committee is holding an an

nytimes_articles.headline: Leader of H.U.D. Assesses It Harshly
nytimes_articles.abstract: Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros acknowledged today that his agency's hapless management of apartment buildings it owns has "exacerbated the declining quality of life in urban America."    In a harsh assessment of the department's shortcomings, Mr. Cisneros told the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee that a wave of defaults on Government-insured mortgages has left the Department of Housing and Urban Development owning a rapidly growing inventory of troubled properties.

nytimes_articles.headline: Forget Fine-Tuning: Mets Seek Overhaul
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Mets, conceding that "we have stunk it up royally," yesterday announced the latest stage of an organizational overhaul for the team with the worst record in baseball.   Al Harazin, the general manager and team executive who had been asked to relinquish control of baseball operations, resigned. And Joe McIlvaine, who was a member of the club's hierarchy when it won the World Series in 1986, is on the verge of rejoining the team as the man charged with returning the Mets to respectability.

nytimes_articles.headline: European Community Sets Terms For 6 Former Soviet Allies to Join
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to criticism that it has done little to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, the European Community formally invited six former Soviet-bloc countries today to join the regional group when their economic and political conditions permit.   No target date for entry was set, and none of the six countries -- Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Romania and Bulgaria -- are likely to be ready for membership before 2000. "We're talking some years ahead," one European official said at the end of a European summit meeting here.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sheffield to Be Arraigned in Absentia
nytimes_articles.abstract: GARY SHEFFIELD of the San Diego Padres faces arraignment on a misdemeanor assault charge today in Houston.   Sheffield will not be present at the hearing -- the Padres will be in San Francisco playing the Giants. The Houston lawyer, CHRIS TRITICO, will represent Sheffield and enter his not guilty plea.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pressure Grows on Azerbaijan Leader to Quit
nytimes_articles.abstract: The former Communist leader of Azerbaijan, Heydar Aliyev, continued today to ratchet up the pressure on President Abulfez Elchibey to resign, saying the President's continued absence from the capital was the cause of general instability.   Even as he spoke, rebel forces calling for the President's resignation casually sauntered around Baku.

nytimes_articles.headline: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hochster and Walker Cup    When the Hochster Memorial was won yesterday by Cliff Earle of McGregor Links in Saratoga, N.Y., it capped a week of celebration at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club. The 77-year-old club in Scarsdale, N.Y., has been quaking with excitment since last Wednesday, when it was awarded its first United States Golf Association event, the 1997 Walker Cup.   "We don't have have a driving range and enough real estate to accommodate a large field," said Rick Vershure, the head pro at Quaker Ridge, "but we have enough room for a small field like the Walker Cup."

nytimes_articles.headline: Japanese Party Crumbles Further As 44 Quit to Form a Rival Group
nytimes_articles.abstract: The breakup of Japan's governing party widened today with the resignation of 44 more rebellious Members of Parliament who prepared to form a new centrist party that could be the core of a coalition government.    The new party will be headed by the former Finance Minister, Tsutomu Hata, a 57-year-old veteran of the governing Liberal Democratic Party. Under some scenarios, Mr. Hata is now in the lead position to become Prime Minister of the new Government. Working behind the scenes is Ichiro Ozawa, 51, the new group's real power and a shrewd political strategist who now threatens to redraw the power structure that has ruled Japan for 38 years.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Case Looks Weaker in Idaho Siege
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Randy Weaver surrendered last August after an 11-day siege at his mountaintop cabin in northern Idaho, Federal officials said they had captured a neo-Nazi fugitive who had plotted an armed confrontation with the authorities.   But now, after a two-month trial and six days of jury deliberations, the Government's image of Mr. Weaver as a political extremist bent on armed conflict has been eclipsed by courtroom revelations. Federal authorities have been sanctioned by the judge for withholding evidence, and the Government's case against Mr. Weaver has been contradicted by its own witnesses.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hextall Is Following His Family Tradition
nytimes_articles.abstract: His father was a hockey player. His uncle was a hockey player. His grandfather was a hockey player, too. "My mum remembers me when I was 2 years old," Ron Hextall was saying today, "and I would throw the socks up the stairs and make the save" when they bounced back.   He figures he was born to be a hockey player. Now that he is an Islander goalie, acquired on Sunday in a trade with Quebec, there is irony about him wearing a New York uniform and trying to keep pucks out of the net.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tobacco Groups Sue to Void Rule On Danger in Secondhand Smoke
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leading forces of the tobacco industry sued the Federal Government yesterday to overturn its declaration that secondhand tobacco smoke causes cancer.   Groups representing tobacco growers and distributors, as well as the country's two leading cigarette makers, Philip Morris Companies Inc. and the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, asked a Federal District Court in Greensboro, N.C., to nullify the designation of smoke from other people's cigarettes as a carcinogen, a classification made by the Environmental Protection Agency last January.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aristide Likely to Meet Army Head This Week
nytimes_articles.abstract: Haiti's deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is expected to meet with his country's military leaders this week in what diplomats say could set the stage for a settlement of the long political crisis.   Diplomats involved in organizing the talks say Haiti's military commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, agreed to the meeting late Monday in response to sharply increased international pressures for a negotiated settlement.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins Questions Tactics Used by Giuliani
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday questioned the campaign tactics of his Republican opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, contending that Mr. Giuliani's recent comments on Crown Heights and rent regulation indicated that he did not have the "temperament" to lead New York City.   Speaking to reporters at the conclusion of the United States Conference of Mayors' meeting in midtown Manhattan, Mr. Dinkins accused Mr. Giuliani of trying to inflame sentiment over the 1991 racial unrest in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Inquiry Sought on Russian Reactors
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations agency overseeing the nuclear power industry called today for an independent international assessment of new evidence Russia has just given it suggesting one of the Chernobyl-type reactors that the major Western nations want shut down is safer than they think.   In a statement here, the International Atomic Energy Agency called for "independent international verification" of the Russian assertions that were presented to a team of 20 nuclear experts from 10 Western countries while they were conducting an intensive examination of this "top of the line" 1,000-megawatt RBMK reactor at Smolensk earlier this month.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Spielberg's New Project? It's a Cartoon Dog's Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Triumphant at the box office with the dinosaurs in "Jurassic Park," Steven Spielberg now trips over a dog. Finally having its premiere on CBS tonight at 8 with two back-to-back half-hour episodes, the animated series "Family Dog," which Mr. Spielberg produced, is about as much fun as a rabies epidemic.    Back in 1987, "Family Dog," written and directed by Brad Bird, was one of the more successful episodes in Mr. Spielberg's rickety television anthology "Amazing Stories." The next step, of course, was to go for a series. Working as executive producer with the director Tim Burton ("Batman"), Mr. Spielberg had 10 episodes finished, at a cost somewhere around $6 million, by the spring of 1991. The problem: The charm of the original was nowhere in sight. One likely reason: Mr. Bird had joined the mass trek of top animators to "The Simpsons."

nytimes_articles.headline: Only Rent Regulations Keep Housing Remotely Affordable
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Like Ronald Reagan's claim that he could balance the budget by cutting taxes and spending more on the military, "Time to Make Sense on Rent Control" (editorial, June 14) contains more right-wing superstition than common sense. How would allowing New York City landlords rent increases lower the cost of housing?

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Warns Russia on Missile-Fuel Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States is trying to block the shipment of rocket-fuel ingredients from Russia to Libya, officials said today. The shipment is the latest in a string of exports that have caused major worry in the Clinton Administration.    With a deteriorating economy, Russia has been increasingly dependent on military sales to earn hard currency.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Questions on Tory Campaign Financing
nytimes_articles.abstract: Already battered by a series of political miscues and polls showing declining support, Britain's Conservative Party is now facing questions about the propriety of its campaign finances, leaving Prime Minister John Major once again on the defensive.   In the latest disclosure, The Guardian reported today that the Conservatives accepted as much as $10.5 million from people with ties to the Saudi Arabian Government just before last year's general election. The Conservative Party's own rules prohibit accepting contributions from foreign governments, although they are not illegal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Jazz Festival; Some Singers Get Together But End Up Sounding Apart
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anita O'Day, Cassandra Wilson and the duo of Nancy Marano and Eddie Monteiro have so little in common that putting them together at Town Hall on Saturday in a JVC Jazz Festival show named "The Jazz Singers" might be called the "variety assortment" school of programming.    Although Ms. O'Day and Ms. Wilson are both free-spirited iconoclasts, they belong to different generations and work out of different traditions. In the 1940's, Ms. O'Day brought an exuberant, rough-tough style of jazz improvisation to big-band singing. Ms. Wilson takes the note-bending innovations of Sarah Vaughan and Betty Carter to much further extremes of spontaneity. Ms. Marano and Mr. Monteiro are traditionalists with highly developed skills in genteel scat singing

nytimes_articles.headline: Save Us All From the White House Press Corps
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Mr. Clinton Picks a Justice" (editorial, June 15) closes an otherwise excellent discussion of President Clinton's Supreme Court nomination by criticizing Mr. Clinton's "intemperate response to a reporter's question about his erratic selection process." Boy, are you wrong!

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Rules That First Lady Is 'De Facto' Federal Official
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ruling that Hillary Rodham Clinton was a full-time Government official, a Federal appeals court today approved the secrecy of her task force on health care and essentially acquiesced in Mrs. Clinton's views about the role and powers of the First Lady.    The ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, came in a case filed by doctors and others seeking to force the panel, the Task Force on National Health Care Reform, to conduct its business in public.

nytimes_articles.headline: Only Rent Regulations Keep Housing Remotely Affordable; Exit the Middle Class
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Time to Make Sense on Rent Control" (editorial, June 14) proposes to cancel protection to "luxury" apartments (whatever that means) and additionally to all tenants whose income exceeds $100,000 a year. State Senator Ralph Marino wants all apartments renting for more than $750 a month decontrolled, as they are "luxury" (perhaps they are in his Long Island constituency).

nytimes_articles.headline: The Contenders for 1994
nytimes_articles.abstract: Twenty-four teams will play in the World Cup in nine U.S. cities, June 17 to July 17.QUALIFIED: .The United States as host, Germany as defending champion, plus Mexico, Greece and Russia. . YET TO QUALIFY: . EUROPE - Thirty-eight entries, 12 qualifying

nytimes_articles.headline: The Senate's Power Grab
nytimes_articles.abstract: In next month's Supreme Court confirmation hearings, the Senate Judiciary Committee will undoubtedly ask Ruth Bader Ginsburg detailed questions about her legal opinions on many divisive political issues. This is a relatively new practice for the committee. For most of U.S. history, the nominee did not even appear before the committee: It was considered beneath the dignity of the office of a Justice. (As the Clarence Thomas hearings showed, that belief has some merit.)   Even when the practice began in the 1930's, the questioning was usually perfunctory or nonexistent. In 1962, Byron R. White was asked only about a dozen questions. William O. Douglas waited outside the hearing room and was finally dismissed without being asked anything in 1939.

nytimes_articles.headline: Save Us All From the White House Press Corps; The Worst of Taste
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   That was no question! The ABC reporter delivered an accusatory speech and tacked a question mark on the end. The speech-question was in the worst of taste and merited President Clinton's response.

nytimes_articles.headline: N.C.A.A. to Hear Ramsey Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly two years after ERIC RAMSEY claimed he received money and other illegal benefits to play football for Auburn, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's committee on infractions will hear the case next Wednesday in Kansas City, Mo.

nytimes_articles.headline: French Immigration Curbs Provoke Cabinet Rift
nytimes_articles.abstract: The conservative Government of Edouard Balladur faced a damaging rift over its drive to clamp down on immigration after a leading Gaullist legislator suggested today that perusing a foreign newspaper in the streets of Paris might be cause enough for the police to demand the identity papers of the reader.   Since taking office in March, Interior Minister Charles Pasqua has embarked on a policy he has called "zero immigration" in response to rapidly rising unemployment. His proposed legislation, including tighter controls on French citizenship and wider identity checks, has tried to tread a fine line falling just short of outright racism.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Easing of Vietnam Trade Sanctions
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration is considering allowing American companies to bid on contracts in Vietnam that are financed by loans from international lending agencies like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, officials said today.   If accepted by the President, such an action, combined with an Administration decision not to block a plan that would give Hanoi access to loans from multilateral lending institutions, would be the most far-reaching easing of the 18-year-old United States trade embargo against its former wartime enemy.

nytimes_articles.headline: Teacher Unions, Long Far Apart, Discuss a Merger
nytimes_articles.abstract: After decades of hostilities, the nation's two main teachers' unions are talking about merging.   The issue will be on the table at the annual meeting of the 2.1-million-member National Education Association in San Francisco next week. The other union, the 820,000-member American Federation of Teachers, has long been open to such a merger. And although people from both unions say that significant differences remain and that an actual merger is a long way off, they also say merging makes sense now.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Iran's political isolation referred incorrectly in some editions to a group of countries that view Iran as a menace. Because the group includes Israel (along with Algeria, Egypt and Tunisia), it should have been characterized as regional, not Islamic.

nytimes_articles.headline: Was He or Wasn't He? Tagliabue to Decide
nytimes_articles.abstract: National Football League Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE is expected to make a decision before the week is out on a Washington Redskins' complaint that the Houston Oilers broke a trade agreement for linebacker WILBER MARSHALL.    Tagliabue will hear from both sides today or tomorrow in either New York or Washington, the N.F.L. said Monday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pazienza Boasts He's Too Tough to Be Counted Out of the Big Time
nytimes_articles.abstract: Given what he has overcome to get to this point, it is not a great leap of faith to believe what former world champion Vinnie Pazienza says: that his neck, once broken and still painful, will not stop him from beating Lloyd Honeyghan in a 12-round middleweight bout Saturday night.   Pazienza is reappearing in the big time as part of a feature that will be headlined by the heavyweight main event between Evander Holyfield, in a comeback of his own, and Alex Stewart.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where Is The Old Bob Dole?
nytimes_articles.abstract: I have such a longstanding respect for Senator Bob Dole that I fantasize that the old Bob Dole -- the responsible statesman -- will weigh back into the budget debate.   He was one of the first Republicans to recognize that the towering Reagan deficits endangered the health of the economy. Ignoring the political risk, he stood up to his own President, who offered supply-side nostrums, blithely talking about "growing out of the deficits" and minimizing their size by basing projections on rosy scenarios.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Little Ado, If You Please, About a Very Special Villa
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's the same room, but the furniture has gone. Gone are the green twin beds, the big oaken chest of drawers I liked so much, even though it was half-eaten by woodworms. All my toys, all my books, my desk. Gone is my childhood bedroom. .The memories ar

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Music; 77 Trombones and a Church
nytimes_articles.abstract: Wendy Mae Chambers's "Mass for Mass Trombones" gives a certain surreal quality to 13th-century formats and acoustical effects. On Saturday night, Ms. Chambers's instrumentation was made up of one solo trombonist, 76 others divided into 11 choirs, and one large church, the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.   She used the last with some effect. The nine sections of the requiem luxuriated in the lazy reverberation time and the energized resonances bouncing around this huge space.

nytimes_articles.headline: Health Insurer Is Investigated By Prosecutor
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, has begun a criminal investigation into Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.   Mr. Morgenthau confirmed yesterday that his office had issued subpoenas this week for documents kept by Empire, the state's largest health insurer. He said he had begun the inquiry, which he described as preliminary, after recent published reports about possible financial irregularities at the company.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Pop Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gabriel's Just Causes   Peter Gabriel is a busy man, as usual.   After five years off the road, the English rocker is touring the world again in a show wrapped in high-tech visuals and special effects. Tonight, he's bringing it to Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands and on Thursday, to Madison Square Garden. The Womad Festival, which he conceived and co-founded in 1980 as a showcase for musicians from developing countries, is coming to the United States this year for the first time.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mexico City Journal; A Glittering Vision of Suburbia Supplants a Dump
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yards from where an army of ragged men hang from rope slings shaping the sides of a strip mining pit on the edge of this city, nearly a dozen modern office buildings are under construction. Except for a few splashes of purple paint, and the manicured cliffs behind them, they would look completely at home in any New Jersey corporate park.    In an adjoining crater also about six miles from the historic center of the city, workers are applying the marble and brass finishing touches to a fancy new shopping mall.

nytimes_articles.headline: Congressional Roundup; Senate Passes a Smaller Stimulus Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate today approved by voice vote a far smaller version of President Clinton's ill-fated economic stimulus package, with fresh financing for summer jobs and child immunization and an unexpected last-minute Republican addition on welfare.   The supplemental appropriations bill is a diminutive orphan of the original $16 billion stimulus package, which was killed on April 21 after a Republican filibuster. The new $1.9 billion bill is not proposed as an economic stimulus because it includes a few million dollars more in cuts than added expenditures, but it will bring some relief to hard-pressed cities.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato misidentified the person with whom he said he would confer about running for governor. It was his mother, Antoinette, not his brother, Armand.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Men and Women and Sex and Power
nytimes_articles.abstract: Fans of talk shows and news programs will have noticed that sexual harassment has replaced date rape as television's offense of the season. Both subjects enjoy that good old man-woman appeal, but, as tonight's edition of CBS's "48 Hours" demonstrates, charges of harassment have more reach and variety.   "When does a word, a look or a touch become a slur, a leer or a grope?" asks Dan Rather at the start of the program, titled "Indecent Proposals." On the show is a Hollywood talent agent who was charged by 11 women (10 aspiring actresses and one undercover police officer) with giving talent tryouts a special meaning; female police officers in Newport Beach, Calif., who sued after what they asserted were years of being manhandled by superiors, and Minnesota women who say they were emotionally scarred by having to endure dirty cracks from boys in their school hallways.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tired After 2 Decades at City Hall, Young Will Retire as Detroit Mayor
nytimes_articles.abstract: After dominating Detroit politics and government for two decades, Coleman A. Young, the first black Mayor of the nation's eighth-largest city, said today that he no longer had the vitality to campaign for office or run a big city and would not seek re-election this fall.   Mr. Young, who is 75 and suffers from emphysema, had kept everyone guessing about his intentions until a news conference this afternoon. For weeks he had told reporters and confidants that he had not decided whether to run for a sixth four-year term.

nytimes_articles.headline: Olerud Is Blue Jays' New King of Swing
nytimes_articles.abstract: The first thing everyone raves about is the swing. John Olerud just might have the prettiest swing in baseball. It is fluid, it is effortless and there is no sense of panic in his eyes or his hands as his bat slides through the strike zone. Olerud simply waits, sees the ball and then strokes it. Beautiful.    But the gorgeous left-handed swing had only produced a .269 career average in three seasons with the Toronto Blue Jays before Olerud tinkered with his mechanics this past spring. He moved his hands away from his body, he backed off the plate to get a better look at pitches and he decided to be more aggressive. No more watching first-pitch strikes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge Says Assistance Center For Homeless Can Stay Closed
nytimes_articles.abstract: A state judge overseeing conditions in New York City's shelter system for homeless families yesterday agreed that a center in lower Manhattan, where families go to apply for shelter, could remain closed.    The center was closed on Friday, following an assault there last week on a caseworker by a homeless woman. The caseworker was kicked in the face and needed 20 stitches.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Some Catholic Girls, Dreams of Serving at Altar Are No Longer Just Dreams
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a child, Barbara Decker dreamed of being an altar server like her older brother, John. Under the rules of the Roman Catholic Church that was impossible -- only boys could serve -- but that didn't keep her from pretending.   At home, she and John would cover a card table with a white cloth. They would pound Wonder Bread into imaginary communion wafers, and with John playing the part of the priest, they would distribute them to their congregation of stuffed animals.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kohl Urges Arming of Bosnian Muslims
nytimes_articles.abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany surprised and irritated his European Community partners by pressing strongly for an end to the arms embargo on Bosnian Muslims at a regional summit meeting that ended here today.   The German leader's appeal was roundly rejected by the other community leaders, but it nonetheless stimulated an intense and at times emotional debate on the Bosnian crisis during a private dinner here Monday night and closed-door negotiations this morning.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: U.S. Seeks to Bar Sale Of Russian Rocket Fuel   As concerns grow over Moscow's military exports to the third world, the United States is trying to block the shipment of Russian rocket fuel ingredients to Libya, officials said. The shipment is the latest in a string of Russian exports that are a major worry for President Clinton. Page A8. Foreign Aid's Many Fans    Foreign aid bills still have enough supporters to sail through Congress, despite legislators' recent focus on domestic affairs. Page A19. Criminal Inquiry Into Empire    The Manhattan District Attorney is investigating Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and has issued subpoenas for company documents. Page B1. Stabbing Outside a School    A 17-year-old student was stabbed and critically injured outside a Queens high school known for its high academic standing. Page B1.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Tina Turner, Wig to High Heels
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Jurassic Park" may be the summer's biggest movie success so far, but the surprise hit is the splashy, highly charged musical melodrama "What's Love Got To Do With It."   Adapted from Tina Turner's autobiography, "I, Tina," written by Ms. Turner and Kurt Loder, the movie chronicles the singer's ferocious 16-year marriage and musical partnership with Ike Turner, the blues musician who discovered her and tore her down by beating and otherwise abusing her. The film was directed by Brian Gibson, from a screenplay by Kate Lanier.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dinkins's Actions on Crown Hts. Become Focus of Mayoral Race
nytimes_articles.abstract: Propelled by the imminent release of a state report on the racial disturbances in Crown Heights, the long-simmering controversy over how the Dinkins administration handled the 1991 violence moved to the forefront of the New York City mayoral campaign yesterday, forcing the Mayor again to defend his record on an issue that has haunted him for two years.   With the long-awaited report commissioned by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo due in two to three weeks, the resurgence of interest in Crown Heights came just as Mayor David N. Dinkins prepared for a trip to Israel intended to portray his support for Jewish causes and to reach out to an ethnic group that could be crucial in the election. On the Deensive    Instead, the Mayor was thrown on the political defensive yesterday, responding to news reports about Crown Heights. In addition to reports that the state inquiry would heavily criticize Mr. Dinkins and his Police Commissioner at the time, Lee P. Brown, several police officers asserted that superiors had ordered them not to make arrests as youths rampaged through the Brooklyn neighborhood, overturning cars and hurling stones and bottles at police lines.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pulling Out of Fort Apache, the Bronx; New 41st Precinct Station House Leaves Behind Symbol of Community's Past Troubles
nytimes_articles.abstract: "It was bad," George Hankins said as he sat in the shade in the South Bronx, his 260-pound boxer's body bending the chair beneath him. "When I first came to the precinct there were the youth gangs: Savage Skulls, Savage Nomads, Ghetto Brothers, Black Spades, Spanish Mafia, Seven Immortals, Seven Crowns."   He stretched his memory back 25 years to his days as a rookie patrolman in the 41st Precinct, whose station house was known from here to Hollywood as Fort Apache, a solitary outpost in a neighborhood of death and decay and gangs with grandiosely macabre names.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Balanchine Showcases For Team Technique
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Balanchine, willing to take risks and to unnerve his audience, choreographed essentially for himself. Yet he was also a great entertainer, and some of his boldest experiments became his most obvious crowd pleasers.   The 1977 "Vienna Waltzes," one of his biggest box-office hits, returned in spectacular form over the weekend as part of the New York City Ballet's Balanchine Celebration. The five-part exploration of waltz rhythms was danced on Saturday night at the New York State Theater, sharing the bill with other new festival entries, "Ballo della Regina" and "Kammermusik No. 2." "Vienna Waltzes" was repeated on Sunday afternoon and again in the evening, when Margaret Tracey made an unscheduled debut in the ballet's classical third section.

nytimes_articles.headline: McCall Selects a Deputy
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York State Comptroller H. Carl McCall has nominated Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to be his deputy in charge of monitoring New York City. The office of the Deputy Comptroller for New York City audits the city's budget and its agencies for the state. Ms. Scanlon will be paid $102,335. Under Ms. Scanlon, the office will go beyond its role as a fiscal monitor and begin working with the mayor's office to improve the city's economic condition, Mr. McCall said. Ms. Scanlon's appointment is subject to review by the State Senate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unseeded, Not Uncheered
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two sights make Zina Garrison-Jackson happy: her entourage and the green, green grass of Wimbledon, where she was a finalist in 1990. After a nasty spat with Pam Shriver last week, Garrison-Jackson felt comfortable today in a 6-2, 7-5 victory over Sabine Hack of Germany.   Garrison-Jackson had a dozen family members and friends standing on the edge of Court 4 as she scampered on her favorite surface. There were also dozens of black fans in the crowded aisles to watch the leading black female player, who is currently ranked 21st and unseeded here.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Too Much Is Too Much' : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "A Newly Excellent German Politics, Please" (Opinion, June 2): .Relaxing the immigration criteria for Germany as proposed will not solve but simply aggravate the problem, which is economic and not racial. Like most of my compatriots

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Incumbents in the top leadership positions of the National Organization for Women are routinely challenged in elections, and this year, when 3,000 delegates to the annual convention are expected to cast ballots in Boston on July 3, will be no exception.    Contending that the administration of PATRICIA IRELAND has lost touch with the grass roots, a team headed by EFIA NWANGAZA, a lawyer from Greenville, S.C., is seeking office.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Design vs. the Environment: A Debate Among Architects
nytimes_articles.abstract: You can walk to McCormick Place, but not without dodging cars. Though it is just minutes away by foot from the Loop, the cavernous convention center is so isolated from the rest of Chicago by the traffic streaming past that most visitors arrive and depart by taxi or bus.  Intentionally or not, the building is a perfect example of the problem addressed over the weekend by the more than 6,000 architects who gathered at McCormick Place: the extent to which architecture has contributed to the global environmental crisis.   Automobile traffic is only part of the problem. Roughly half the world's energy consumption goes into the construction, maintenance and operation of buildings. Architects don't initiate this gross consumption, but some of them have begun to recognize that design can help curtail it.  The choice of building materials, use of renewable resources like natural light and ventilation, and controlled patterns of suburban growth are some of the strategies architects can adopt toward what is called sustainable development: design that provides shelter without environmental or human exploitation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Legislative Chiefs Agree to Extend Rent Rules Briefly
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the second time in a week, Senate and Assembly leaders agreed today to extend the state's rent regulations for a brief period while they continue discussing whether to weaken regulations on certain luxury apartments.    Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., agreed this afternoon to extend the existing rent law for seven days. Both houses are expected to approve the extension on Wednesday.
